data.title: Dangerous (1935)
data.meta_description: Dan Bellows finds former stage star Joyce Heath a penniless drunk and takes her to his Connecticut home for rehabilitation. He asks his fiancée Gail to free him and offers to sponsor Joyce in a play.
data.text:
People say old movies aren't entertaining or relatable, but I'm totally envious of Bette Davis sitting in a Depression-era bar tossing back 10¢ shots of straight gin.

Bette Davis was a great actress and has flashes of greatness in Dangerous - one moment, where she is playing cards late at night with her beau, hair a mess and chewing with her mouth open, presents an angle that few leading ladies of the time would dare to take on, and she completely delivers without becoming silly. However, this film is not great or even good; it's a relatively tacky and silly melodrama with unimpressive screen chemistry and a series of grand gestures that come up short (at one point, Davis tries…

“I want you. But I’m through begging.”

Bette Davis is slovenly again, discovered by Franchot Tone in a basement bar drinking straight gin. Once she dries out, Davis, as fallen Broadway star Joyce Heath, is quite charming in her subtle seduction of Tone’s not-so-secretly smitten (but engaged) architect. You can understand why Don Bellows (Tone) would otherwise quickly leave his fiancé (if she didn’t have so many connections to help his career), because Joyce has it (and for him, looks enticingly like a woman that needs saving–and kissing–when she’s soaked to the bone in the pouring rain). As Alison Skipworth’s character warns, “a bad woman’s got something a good woman ain’t, and a good woman’s jealous of that something, and…

*SOME SPOILERS*

For 50 minutes, this is a quite brilliant drama of sexual obsession, with Franchot Tone as an architect falling for a boozy, washed-up actress (Bette Davis) who's 'jinxed' a half-dozen men, as well as half of Broadway.

It's not dissimilar to Of Human Bondage (it even trades on the likeness in the trailer), the film that made Davis's name the previous year and in which her filthy commoner drove Leslie Howard half-insane, though the tone – like its leading man – is a little lighter, while her character is smarter, more sentimental and much more likeable than the cruel, gobby waitress she played there.

It's interesting how much this movie's concerns foreshadow film noir, in which happily married…
